title: Meta Buys Startup Manus in Latest Move to Advance Its Artificial Intelligence Efforts
shortdescription: Meta has acquired artificial intelligence startup Manus as part of its broader strategy to strengthen AI development and accelerate innovation across its platforms.
description: Meta has acquired artificial intelligence startup Manus in a strategic move aimed at deepening its capabilities in advanced AI development, reinforcing the company’s long-term vision of embedding artificial intelligence across its products and services. The acquisition reflects Meta’s ongoing effort to compete with other technology giants in an increasingly crowded AI landscape, where innovation, talent, and proprietary technology have become critical advantages. Manus, known for its work in applied AI systems and automation, is expected to bring specialized expertise and engineering talent that can be integrated into Meta’s existing research teams, supporting initiatives ranging from content recommendation and advertising optimization to safety systems and immersive digital experiences. Although financial details of the deal were not disclosed, industry analysts view the acquisition as part of Meta’s broader approach of absorbing nimble startups to accelerate development timelines and reduce reliance on external vendors. Meta has consistently emphasized that AI sits at the core of its future strategy, influencing how users interact with social platforms, how creators reach audiences, and how businesses connect with consumers. In recent years, the company has increased investment in AI infrastructure, large language models, and custom hardware, even as it balances cost controls and regulatory scrutiny. The purchase of Manus also highlights the growing value of AI startups as acquisition targets, as demand for skilled researchers and scalable technology intensifies across the industry. At the same time, Meta faces ongoing questions about responsible AI deployment, including concerns related to data privacy, transparency, and the societal impact of automated systems. Integrating Manus into Meta’s ecosystem will require aligning the startup’s technology with the company’s internal governance frameworks while maintaining the innovative momentum that made the acquisition attractive in the first place. As artificial intelligence continues to reshape the technology sector, Meta’s acquisition of Manus signals its determination to remain a leading force in shaping how AI tools are developed and deployed, positioning the company to compete aggressively as AI becomes increasingly central to digital communication, commerce, and entertainment.

title: Trump Delays Increased Tariffs on Upholstered Furniture, Kitchen Cabinets and Vanities for a Year
shortdescription: Former President Donald Trump has delayed planned tariff increases on upholstered furniture, kitchen cabinets, and vanities for one year, easing pressure on importers and consumers.
description: Former President Donald Trump has delayed the implementation of higher tariffs on upholstered furniture, kitchen cabinets, and vanities for one year, a move that offers temporary relief to manufacturers, retailers, and consumers amid ongoing concerns about costs and supply chains. The tariff increases, which were originally scheduled to take effect sooner, were part of broader trade measures aimed at protecting domestic industries but faced criticism from businesses that warned of higher prices and reduced consumer demand. By postponing the tariffs, the administration signaled a willingness to balance trade enforcement goals with economic realities, particularly as inflation concerns and housing-related expenses remain sensitive issues for households. Industry groups representing furniture makers, home builders, and retailers welcomed the delay, noting that the added costs would likely have been passed on to consumers at a time when affordability remains a challenge. Importers also argued that supply chains for these products are complex and globally integrated, making it difficult to quickly shift sourcing without disrupting availability or quality. The delay provides companies with additional time to adjust sourcing strategies, renegotiate contracts, or invest in domestic production where feasible, though uncertainty remains about whether the tariffs will ultimately take effect after the one-year postponement. Critics of the tariffs have long maintained that such measures function as indirect taxes on consumers, raising prices without delivering clear benefits to domestic manufacturers, while supporters argue they are necessary to counter unfair trade practices and encourage U.S.-based production. The decision highlights the ongoing tension in U.S. trade policy between protectionist impulses and the practical impact on businesses and consumers. As the one-year delay begins, stakeholders across the furniture and home goods industries are closely watching for further guidance, aware that future tariff decisions could influence pricing, investment, and employment. The postponement underscores how trade policy continues to play a significant role in shaping everyday consumer costs, even as broader debates over tariffs and globalization persist.

title: China’s Economy Looks More Resilient Than It Feels as a Property Slump Drags On
shortdescription: China’s economy continues to show signs of resilience in official data, but prolonged weakness in the property sector is weighing heavily on confidence among businesses and consumers.
description: China’s economy appears more resilient on paper than it feels on the ground, as steady growth indicators and government support measures contrast sharply with the prolonged drag from a deepening property slump that continues to sap confidence. Official data point to stabilization in manufacturing, exports, and infrastructure investment, suggesting that policymakers have succeeded in preventing a sharp slowdown through targeted stimulus and regulatory adjustments. However, the ongoing downturn in the real estate sector, long a pillar of household wealth and local government revenue, has created a persistent sense of unease among consumers and businesses alike. Property sales remain weak, developers continue to struggle with debt, and unfinished housing projects have undermined trust in the market, making families more cautious about spending and investment. The psychological impact of falling home prices has proven difficult to offset, even as other parts of the economy show signs of improvement. Economists note that while China has avoided a crisis-style collapse, the slow erosion of confidence poses a longer-term challenge that is harder to address with traditional stimulus tools. Local governments, heavily reliant on land sales, face fiscal strain that limits their ability to support growth, while banks remain cautious about extending credit to the property sector despite policy encouragement. At the same time, policymakers are attempting to rebalance the economy toward manufacturing, technology, and green industries, promoting areas such as electric vehicles and renewable energy as new growth drivers. These sectors have delivered pockets of strength, but they have yet to fully compensate for the scale of the property downturn. For households, the disconnect between headline economic resilience and everyday financial anxiety has become increasingly pronounced, shaping cautious behavior that restrains consumption. Analysts warn that without a clearer resolution to the property slump, China risks settling into a period of subdued growth marked by weak sentiment, even if outright recession is avoided. As 2026 begins, the challenge for Chinese leaders lies in restoring confidence without reigniting speculative excess, balancing stability with reform in an economy that looks stable from afar but feels fragile to many at home.

title: South Korea’s Climate Pledge to Cut Coal, Lower Emissions Clash With U.S. Push for LNG Purchases
shortdescription: South Korea’s commitment to reduce coal use and cut emissions is increasingly at odds with U.S. pressure to boost long-term purchases of liquefied natural gas, highlighting tensions between climate goals and energy security.
description: South Korea’s ambitious climate pledges to phase down coal use and sharply reduce greenhouse gas emissions are colliding with growing pressure from the United States to increase long-term purchases of liquefied natural gas, exposing a complex tension between decarbonization goals, energy security, and geopolitical alliances. As one of Asia’s largest energy importers, South Korea has committed to achieving carbon neutrality by mid-century, with plans to cut reliance on coal-fired power and expand renewable energy, nuclear generation, and energy efficiency measures. However, U.S. officials and energy exporters have increasingly promoted LNG as a reliable alternative to coal and a cornerstone of energy cooperation, urging Seoul to lock in long-term contracts that would support American producers and strengthen bilateral ties. While LNG emits less carbon dioxide than coal when burned, climate advocates argue that expanded gas infrastructure risks locking South Korea into fossil fuel dependence for decades, complicating its emissions-reduction pathway and undermining investments in renewables. South Korean policymakers face a delicate balancing act, as LNG plays a critical role in ensuring stable electricity supply, particularly during peak demand and periods when renewable generation fluctuates. At the same time, domestic political pressure is growing to align energy policy more closely with climate commitments, as public concern over air quality, extreme weather, and global climate responsibility intensifies. The debate reflects broader global challenges faced by countries attempting to transition away from fossil fuels while managing economic competitiveness and diplomatic relationships. Energy analysts note that while LNG can serve as a transitional fuel, overreliance could delay the deployment of cleaner technologies and increase long-term costs if global climate regulations tighten further. For the United States, promoting LNG exports aligns with economic interests and strategic influence, but it also raises questions about consistency with international climate objectives. As negotiations and policy decisions continue, South Korea’s experience illustrates the difficult trade-offs confronting governments navigating the energy transition, where climate ambition, market realities, and geopolitical pressures increasingly intersect.

title: Trump Overturned Decades of U.S. Trade Policy in 2025. See the Impact of His Tariffs, in Four Charts
shortdescription: A sweeping expansion of tariffs in 2025 marked a dramatic break from decades of U.S. trade policy, reshaping global commerce and domestic prices, as illustrated through four key economic charts.
description: In 2025, former President Donald Trump upended decades of U.S. trade policy by dramatically expanding the use of tariffs, marking a sharp departure from the free-trade consensus that had guided both Republican and Democratic administrations for generations, and the effects of those decisions are visible across the economy when viewed through four key data trends. One set of charts shows a rapid rise in average U.S. tariff rates, reversing a long decline that began after World War II and accelerated with globalization, as new duties were imposed across a wide range of imported goods. Another highlights the concentration of tariffs on consumer products and industrial inputs, illustrating how measures intended to protect domestic manufacturing filtered through supply chains and raised costs for businesses and households alike. A third chart tracks shifts in trade flows, revealing how imports from some countries declined while sourcing moved to alternative markets rather than returning fully to U.S. production, underscoring economists’ long-standing warnings that tariffs often rearrange trade rather than eliminate it. The fourth chart focuses on price impacts, showing how tariff-related costs contributed to higher prices in certain categories, adding to inflationary pressures during an already sensitive economic period. Together, the data illustrate how the tariff strategy reshaped incentives, disrupted long-established trade relationships, and introduced new uncertainty for companies planning investment and sourcing decisions. Supporters of the policy argued that the tariffs restored leverage to the United States and pushed trading partners toward fairer terms, while critics contended that the costs fell disproportionately on American consumers and businesses. Analysts note that beyond immediate price effects, the longer-term consequence may be a structural shift in how the U.S. engages with the global economy, with trade policy becoming a more overtly political tool rather than a technocratic one. The charts also show how quickly trade norms that once seemed stable can change when policy priorities shift, reinforcing the idea that globalization is neither inevitable nor irreversible. As policymakers and businesses assess the legacy of 2025, the data-driven picture makes clear that the tariff surge did more than alter trade statistics; it fundamentally redefined the role of tariffs in U.S. economic strategy and reignited debate over protectionism, competitiveness, and the future of global trade.

title: Shares Are Higher in Asia in an Upbeat Start to the New Year
shortdescription: Asian stock markets opened the new year on a positive note, with shares rising across the region as investors welcomed fresh optimism and steady global cues.
description: Shares across Asia rose in an upbeat start to the new year, reflecting renewed investor optimism as markets reopened following the holiday break and global sentiment improved. Major indexes in the region posted early gains, supported by positive cues from Wall Street, easing inflation expectations, and hopes for steady economic growth in 2026. Investors appeared encouraged by signs of resilience in the global economy, with particular attention on interest rate outlooks, commodity prices, and policy signals from major central banks. In several markets, technology and export-oriented stocks led advances, benefiting from expectations of stable demand and continued innovation-driven growth. The positive tone also reflected relief that no major economic shocks greeted the start of the year, allowing investors to reposition portfolios after a volatile 2025 marked by geopolitical tensions and shifting monetary policy. Analysts noted that early-year trading often carries a symbolic boost, as fresh capital flows and renewed risk appetite can lift markets in the absence of negative news. However, they cautioned that underlying challenges remain, including uneven growth across regions, lingering concerns about China’s property sector, and uncertainty around global trade policy. Despite these risks, the broad gains across Asian markets signaled cautious confidence that the new year could bring more stability than the last. Currency movements were relatively muted, while bond markets showed limited reaction as investors focused on equities. As trading volumes gradually return to normal following the holidays, market participants will be watching upcoming economic data and corporate earnings for confirmation that the early optimism can be sustained. For now, the positive start in Asia has set a constructive tone for global markets as 2026 gets underway.

title: Wall Street Falls in Light Trading on the Final Day of 2025, Another Banner Year for Markets
shortdescription: U.S. stocks slipped in light trading on the final day of 2025, closing out a strong year for markets marked by resilience, easing inflation pressures, and steady investor confidence.
description: Wall Street edged lower in light trading on the final day of 2025 as investors wrapped up another banner year for markets, with modest declines reflecting routine profit-taking rather than a shift in broader sentiment. With many institutional investors already away for the holidays, trading volumes were thin, amplifying small market moves as major indexes closed the books on a year defined by strong gains and repeated resilience in the face of economic uncertainty. Throughout 2025, markets navigated concerns over interest rates, inflation, geopolitical tensions, and slowing global growth, yet equities remained supported by solid corporate earnings, a resilient labor market, and growing optimism that inflation was easing without tipping the economy into recession. Technology and growth-oriented stocks played a significant role in driving gains, buoyed by continued enthusiasm around artificial intelligence and innovation-led productivity, while other sectors benefited from steady consumer spending and business investment. Analysts noted that year-end pullbacks are common after extended rallies and often reflect portfolio rebalancing rather than deteriorating fundamentals. Bond markets also ended the year relatively stable, with yields reflecting expectations that central banks may begin easing monetary policy in the year ahead. Despite periodic volatility during the year, investor confidence remained largely intact, reinforced by the absence of major economic shocks and the ability of companies to adapt to higher borrowing costs. As markets turn the page to 2026, questions remain about valuations, the pace of future rate cuts, and the durability of economic growth, but the close of 2025 leaves Wall Street on solid footing. The quiet dip on the final trading day served as a reminder that short-term fluctuations are a normal part of investing, while the broader story of 2025 remains one of strength, adaptability, and sustained optimism across U.S. financial markets.

title: Stocks Edge Lower as 2025 Winds Down While Gold and Silver Rise
shortdescription: Stocks slipped modestly as 2025 came to a close, while gold and silver prices rose, reflecting cautious positioning and safe-haven demand at year’s end.
description: Stocks edged lower as 2025 wound down, with investors showing restraint in thin year-end trading while turning toward traditional safe-haven assets such as gold and silver, which posted gains. With many market participants already sidelined for the holidays, muted trading volumes amplified small market moves, contributing to modest declines across major stock indexes. The subdued equity performance reflected routine profit-taking after a strong year rather than a shift in underlying confidence, as investors reassessed portfolios and locked in gains ahead of the new year. In contrast, precious metals benefited from renewed interest as a hedge against uncertainty, supported by expectations that central banks may ease monetary policy in 2026 and by lingering concerns over inflation, geopolitics, and global growth. Gold prices climbed as investors sought stability, while silver also advanced, buoyed by both its safe-haven appeal and its role in industrial applications tied to energy transition technologies. Analysts noted that the divergence between equities and precious metals at year’s end is a common feature of late-December trading, when defensive positioning often increases amid low liquidity. Throughout 2025, markets demonstrated resilience despite bouts of volatility driven by interest rate uncertainty, geopolitical tensions, and shifting economic data, leaving stocks near elevated levels even as the year closed on a softer note. Bond markets showed limited movement, signaling that investors remain focused on the outlook for inflation and potential policy changes rather than short-term market fluctuations. As attention turns to 2026, market participants are weighing whether easing financial conditions and steady economic growth can sustain equity gains, while continued interest in gold and silver underscores a desire for balance between risk-taking and protection. The final trading sessions of 2025 thus reflected a cautious but orderly transition into the new year, marked by modest stock declines and a rise in assets traditionally viewed as stores of value.

title: How to Build an Emergency Fund, Pay Off Debt and Make a Plan for Your Money in 2026
shortdescription: Financial experts say 2026 is the right time to focus on building an emergency fund, tackling debt strategically, and creating a realistic plan for managing your money.
description: Building a strong financial foundation in 2026 begins with three essential priorities: creating an emergency fund, paying down debt in a structured way, and developing a clear, realistic plan for managing money amid economic uncertainty. An emergency fund serves as a financial safety net, protecting households from unexpected expenses such as medical bills, job loss, or urgent repairs, and experts generally recommend saving enough to cover three to six months of essential expenses, though even a smaller cushion can significantly reduce stress. Automating savings, starting with modest contributions, and keeping funds in an easily accessible account can help make emergency saving a consistent habit rather than an afterthought. At the same time, paying off debt remains a critical step toward financial stability, particularly high-interest obligations like credit cards that can quickly undermine progress through compounding interest. Financial planners often recommend choosing a clear strategy, such as prioritizing debts with the highest interest rates to minimize long-term costs or focusing on smaller balances first to build momentum and motivation. Making minimum payments on all debts while directing extra funds toward a chosen target can help accelerate repayment without damaging credit. Creating a money plan ties these goals together by assigning purpose to income, balancing necessities, savings, debt reduction, and discretionary spending. Rather than rigid budgets that can be difficult to sustain, many experts encourage flexible spending plans that allow for adjustments as expenses and priorities change. Reviewing income, fixed costs, and variable spending at the start of the year can reveal opportunities to cut unnecessary expenses, renegotiate bills, or redirect bonuses and tax refunds toward savings or debt. Planning for 2026 also means accounting for broader economic factors such as inflation, interest rates, and job market conditions, and building adaptability into financial decisions. Regular check-ins throughout the year can help track progress and make timely adjustments, ensuring goals remain achievable. Importantly, building an emergency fund and paying off debt are not mutually exclusive, and many people benefit from working on both simultaneously. By focusing on consistency, intentional choices, and clear priorities, individuals can enter 2026 with greater confidence, resilience, and control over their financial future.
